A Appendix A.1 Demand estimation In the terminology of BLP, the nonlinear parameters for our models are ÃÅ½ÃÂ²p, ÃÂÃÆp, and ÃÂÃÆl. We search over these parameters using a global optimization algorithm initially (differential evolution), and then we switch to Nelder-Meade. A.2 Demand data We aggregate demand over time and products. We define a product as all UPC codes that share a volume, value for the light beer dummy, and brand. The revenues and quantities (in units of six packs) are added up across such UPC codes for each month, and then prices are recovered by dividing revenues by quantities.

We aggregate stores according to DominickÃÂ¢Ãâ¬Ãâ¢s pricing zones. See Hellerstein (2008) for details. At the UPC-week level, we define an ÃÂ¢Ãâ¬ÃÂon-saleÃÂ¢Ãâ¬ÃÂ dummy that is equal to unity if and only if any sort of promotional activity was recorded in the DominicksÃÂ¢Ãâ¬Ãâ¢ data for that UPC and week. Then, when aggregating the data across stores, weeks, and UPCs, we take the mean value of this dummy as our product-level measure of sales/promotional activity. The ÃÂ¢Ãâ¬ÃÂnumber of products on saleÃÂ¢Ãâ¬ÃÂ instrumental variable is the sum of our product-level sales/promotion measure over products within a market.

Capital is constructed in two ways. For the majority of plants, including all plants in the CMF, capital is measured using a question on total assets ÃÂ¢Ãâ¬Ãâ be they machines or buildings ÃÂ¢Ãâ¬Ãâ at the plant. For the remaining observations, capital is constructed using the perpetual inventory method, using industry-specific depreciation rates and investment deflators from the Bureau of Economic Analysis and the National Bureau of Economic Research. Capital, materials and sales are deflated using the NBER-CES industry-level deflators into 1997 dollars. Our output measure is the total value of product shipments (deflated). Labor inputs are measured by total production hours. Materials inputs are measured by total expenditure on materials, electiricity, and fuel.
